body:
I don't quite understand the benefit of comparing T0 to T0 when there is
only one T0? Is this intentional?

On Tue, Dec 9, 2014 at 9:13 AM, ianlancetaylor <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> On Tue, Dec 9, 2014 at 4:02 AM, robmurtha <notifications@github.com>
> wrote:
> > The following text is taken from the type identity example, it does not
> seem
> > consistent when comparing T0, []int, and struct{ a, b *T5 } to
> themselves.
>
> Why not?
>
> Ian
>
> > copied text
> >
> > Given the declarations
> >
> > type (
> > T0 []string
> > T1 []string
> > T2 struct{ a, b int }
> > T3 struct{ a, c int }
> > T4 func(int, float64) *T0
> > T5 func(x int, y float64) *[]string
> > )
> > these types are identical:
> >
> > T0 and T0
> > []int and []int
> > struct{ a, b *T5 } and struct{ a, b *T5 }
> > func(x int, y float64) *[]string and func(int, float64) (result
> *[]string)
> > T0 and T1 are different because they are named types with distinct
> > declarations; func(int, float64) *T0 and func(x int, y float64)
> *[]string
> > are different because T0 is different from []string.
> >
> > —
> > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/golang/go/issues/9226#issuecomment-66287711>.
>



-- 
Rob Murtha
